title: What GQ Editors Read in May
article_text: All products featured on GQ are independently selected by our editors. However, we may receive compensation from retailers and/or from purchases of products through these links. When we’re notscrolling on SSENSE,interviewing celebrities, orthinking about pants, your favoriteGQeditors like to read—a lot. What, exactly, do we like to read? We’re so glad you asked. Earlier this year, I made a resolution with my two close friends to read two books a month. We started a monthly book club to keep us on track, and now, I’m bringing it to work. Whether yourNew Year’s resolutionwas also to read more books, you’re looking to curb blue-light-induced migraines, or you just need a new title to performatively plop on your nightstand, we’ve got you covered. Here’s a round of novels (remember those?), memoirs, sociological texts, and photo books that your friendly neighborhoodGQstaff enjoyed in May. Viola Davis Barnes & Noble Length: 304 pages Three years ago, aBreakfast Club interviewclip of Viola Davis promoting her memoirFinding Metook me out of a major slump. In it, she recalls a quote she reposted on her social media: “You haven't met all the people who are going to love you in your life yet.” She adds, “When you meet all these people who are going to love you, they do not want to meet a vengeful person.” We often get stuck in nihilistic thought patterns that we forget that life isn't something that just has to happen to us, but an experience we can actively shape. This book has done more for me than five years of therapy. I recommend listening to the audiobook, because the EGOT-winner herself narrates it.—Heven Haile, Editorial Operations Manager Taffy Brodesser-Akner Barnes & Noble Length: 464 pages Though the premise of this book is pure drama, Brodesser-Akner’s snarky voice and gossipy tone manages to keep it juicy and surprisingly funny from top to bottom. I should caveat that I have a particular affinity towards books about characters on the verge of, or actively experiencing, mental breakdowns—and that’s precisely what you’re getting here. If reading about spoiled rich kids turned into maladjusted adults embroiled in toxic family drama sounds as good to you as it did to me, then you should grab a copy.—Camille Ramos, Coordinating Producer Macaela MacKenzie Barnes & Noble Length: 336 pages Women's sports is escalating in growth, influence, and coverage—but they've been fighting the good fight for much longer than the recent rise in attention over the past few years. This book helps paint the bigger picture of why the fight for equity in women's sports goes beyond just athletics and into economic equity for women in general.—Brauna Marks, Visuals Editor Eric Schnall Barnes & Noble Length: 296 pages Sweaty, sun-kissed, often about the reckless, sexually-charged self-discovery of the young, the coming-of-age novel is a summer staple for a reason. Eric Schnall’s winsome debutI Make Envy On Your Disco, however, is a reminder that coming into yourself is a lifelong project—and that sometimes that can happen in your late 30s, against the grey, cold climes of Berlin at the turn of the millennium. That city in transition is the perfect backdrop for this perceptive, melancholy story about a New York art advisor who flees to Berlin to escape the anxieties of middle age and long-term relationships. Full of techno, espressos, hot serpentine boys in cafes, well-timed musical cues (from Ace of Base to Edith Piaf), and the occasional tab of ecstasy, it’s a comforting, elegantly-written reminder that there’s life after twink death.—Raymond Ang, Associate Director of Editorial Operations Eleanor Coppola Amazon Length: 304 pages I read this a while ago but pulled it off the shelf again while editing this Francis Ford Coppola interview a few weeks back. Eleanor, who died in 2024, was Coppola’s wife, creative partner, and secret sharer of 62 years but also a writer/director in her own right. You might know her documentaryHearts of Darkness, an essential portrait of her husband battling self-doubt and all manner of jungle madness in the Philippines while shootingApocalypse Now, which he’s convinced is going to be a career-endingly bad movie;Notes, drawn from Eleanor’s diaries during the Apocalypse era, is no less action-packed and glamorous but also more intimate and thorny in its depiction of Eleanor's relationship with the angst-ridden and sometimes feckless Francis Ford. Parts of it feel like a high-‘70sLost in Translation, even before Eleanor takes Sofia on a train to Kyoto.—Alex Pappademas, Culture Director George W.S. Trow Amazon Length: 112 pages This book-length essay, originally published inThe New Yorkerin 1984, is an almost hypnotic piece of avant-garde magazine writing and reporting—so obliquely rendered as to nearly elude summary. At the surface, it’s a story about the management of a laboratory-forest gifted to Harvard for the study of silviculture. (Yawn? I know.) But it becomes a wholly idiosyncratic and deliriously self-indulgent (non-derogatory!) journey through history. What do the letters of Teddy Roosevelt, the market-value method of accounting, and Soviet physicist Pyotr Kapitsa’s 1966 address to the Royal Society all have to do with a 3,800-acre Hudson Valley forest? Something about how the fallenness of our world stops us from knowing it, freely and simply.—Matthew Browne, Sr. Research Manager Jamie Kreiner Barnes & Noble Length: 288 pages When Jamie Kreiner’sThe Wandering Mind: What Medieval Monks Tell Us About Distractioncame out a few years ago, many reviews noted that our propensity to easily lose focus was not just a modern problem exacerbated by new technologies, but rather a situation that has afflicted humans since time immemorial (or at least in this case, since monks started keeping records of their mental intrusions). Reading about how monks grappled with a “parallel commitment,” juggling concentration on a higher power with more earthly obligations, was especially compelling. “A good renunciation story was aspirational but impossible. The world could not be left behind, not completely,” she observes. One potential solution? “To tackle distraction," Kreiner writes, "it was crucial to identify something worthy of total concentration.” After all, whether sacred or secular, many of us wish to transcend the petty interruptions that keep us from reaching the divine (whatever that might be).—Julia Pagnamenta, Research Manager Jason Jules & Graham Marsh Barnes & Noble Length: 224 pages So many advancements in African American men’s fashion have been aspirational in nature. This was as true during the US mid-century as in our more recent hip-hop style palettes.Black Ivy’s deep captions and ample photos explore, in page after vivid page, Civil Rights Era style icons—ranging from artists to academics to athletes to activists—who pull inspiration from Brooks Brothers’ crisp yet staid prepwear. In the process of Black adaptation and recontextualization, upper-class WASP signifiers such as button-downs, sack suits, and penny loafers were transformed, via remixes and mashups, from cold to cool. And on a personal level, thanks to this essential volume, as a literal child of the ’60s whose classic fashion sense is often mistaken for white preppy instead of being seen as drawing from my true Black inspirations, I finally feel seen.—Gaylord Fields, Copy Manager

title: What Will Be the Shoe of Summer 2025? 7 Menswear Experts Weigh In
article_text: All products featured on GQ are independently selected by our editors. However, we may receive compensation from retailers and/or from purchases of products through these links. Just about every summer, a shoe of the moment emerges in menswear circles. Perhaps no silhouette is more emblematic of this phenomenon thanthe Adidas Samba, the classic sneaker that heldsustained ‘It shoe’ status for several seasons running. These days, however, the world of men’s footwear has become more daring and sprawling than ever. New contenders for the top spot have emerged recently, fromballet-inspiredsilhouettes andheeled leather mulesto the super sleek kicks we lovingly calltornado sneakers. And this is to say nothing ofthe trusty loafersandother classic shoe stylesthat have surged in recent years. (Not to mentionthe straight-up soccer cleatsfolks are now wearing on the pavement?) This summer, the battle for shoe supremacy is as wide open as ever. To help us determine which footwear style will reign supreme during the summer of 2025, we tapped some men’s fashion pros for their predictions. And while the slender sneaker is undoubtedly poised for a big summer, our menswear insiders also pointed to minimalist loafers, freaky oxfords, and lug-soled boat shoes as potential breakout stars, just to name a few. Let the summer shoe games begin. Menswear mainstayBruce Paskbelieves the low-profile sneaker is “definitely looking to be the hit of the summer.” Guys should have no trouble finding a style that suits them, he said, as designers are offering the silhouette in countless colors and materials—ranging from earthy, understated suedes to adventurous hues like blush pink and safety orange. And while the look might be the year’s buzziest trend, Pask is certain you’ll get plenty of mileage out of them: “They’re surprisingly versatile. Great with shorts, denim, and pants, from skinny to wide-legged.” ​​When the occasion calls for a dressier look, Pask said he will be wearing airy, open-weave leather loafers or lace-ups, which offer a breezy summer take on the more classic style. Lastly, he praised the effortlessness and versatility of a well-structured leather sandal: “I like the freshness of the fisherman sandal for summer looks, worn with shorts or trousers, with and without socks—whatever suits your style.” Bottega Veneta Saks Fifth Avenue Bottega Veneta Neiman Marcus Ralph Lauren Purple Label Saks Fifth Avenue Christian Louboutin Neiman Marcus “We’re in a moment where more and more people, myself included, are thinking about how to push menswear into [a more] interesting space from a footwear standpoint,” explainedDrew Joiner, the popular menswear creator andpodcast host. Joiner pointed to a pair of made-to-orderoxfordshe recently picked up fromMarcos Hjornthat illustrate how a few tweaks on a classic men’s shoe can make it feel totally new. While he has plenty of recommendations for slimmer sneakers—the sporty Aime Leon Dore x New Balance RC56, vintagePrada Monte Carlo sneakers, the Taekwondo andJapansilhouettes from Adidas—Joiner is particularly passionate about a pair of low-profile loafers at the moment. The legendary G.H. Bass’s Larson Venetian loafer forgoes the classic vamp and braided detailing of a penny loaferfor a silhouette that’s delightfully sleek and minimalist. In other words, it’s a torpedo sneaker in loafer form. “It almost just looks like a slip-on [sneaker], but it’s a loafer,” he said. “You’re playing with the ballet aesthetic. You’re playing with classic menswear. You’re playing with tailoring. But the details add that 10% twist to the shoe, and it becomes something that’s really fun.” G.H. Bass G.H. Bass Adidas END. Britt Theodora—the celebrity stylist who memorably turnedPete Davidsonontocustom Uggs—offered a wildcard prediction for the breakout footwear hit of the summer. “I think we will see a ton of boots,” she said. “I just got a pair ofR.M.Williamsboots for my boyfriend, who will be adding them into his summer shoe rotation.” (Pedro Pascal, for one, got the Hot Boot Summer memo early.) Theodora also offered advice for elevating your footwear this summer: lean into texture. “If you’re a classic sneaker guy, maybe lean into a suede or metallic leather. You can’t go wrong with Dries [Van Noten] here.” The Belgian label has long put out interesting sneakers. This season is no exception: the brand’s of-the-moment runner comes in everything fromchestnut suedetograssy greento metallic silver leathers andsleek black mesh. R.M. Williams R.M. Williams Dries Van Noten SSENSE David Rivera, who leads creative for Los Angeles streetwear stalwartThe Hundreds, is all about embracing comfort this summer. His summertime sneaker rotation includes a mix of vintage and contemporary Nikes, including theAir Max 95and theAir Max Sunder, with someROA bootsthrown in for good measure. Like many of our experts, he predicted we’ll see a lot of low-profile sneakers this summer, “The fashion cycle is shifting...a more tailored aesthetic is emerging. It’s starting with pants and flowing down to slimmer footwear.” Rivera called out a couple of especially strong styles within the slim-shoe wave:Tyler, the Creator’s Converse 1908, Nike’s soccer-inspired Total 90s, and thePuma Speedcat. But he was also quick to note not to be shy about wearing leather dress shoes throughout the summer, especially withsome crisp white socksand shorts. “It adds contrast and creates this nice balance between polished and relaxed.” Nike Dover Street Market Bode Bode “Expect soccer-inspired sneakers and similarly sleek silhouettes to dominate this season and beyond,” said longtime New York menswear fixtureJian DeLeon. The Nordstrom style guru also suggested not limiting the slimmed-down silhouette to just sneakers, either. “Low-profile soles are a great way to refresh your summer shoe rotation, especially in classic styles like boat shoes and penny loafers.” And if you’re looking for an elevated sandal, DeLeon added that it’s hard to beat thefisherman sandal, a style that has been trending upwards for a few summers now. Jacquemus Nordstrom Vinny's Nordstrom Through his newsletterStreet Night Live, Eugene Lardy covers men’s fashion with the feverish eye of a true obsessive in tune with every changing wind of microtrend. “I’m assuming that we are still going to see a lot of Adidas on the streets, but maybe we’re going to see people trade the Sambas for the BW Army or other GAT-inspired sneakers,” said Lardy. However, if you’re looking for a sneaker that isn’t from the Three Stripes, he also recommended the menswear-diehard-approvedMephisto Cruiser: “A great balance between casual and dressed up.” One non-sneaker style that Lardy is especially hyped about for the season is Timberland’s 3-Eye boat shoe, an ultra-rugged riff on the maritime staple. “​​[It’s] so successful because of the combat midsole. It creates this hybrid look that’s fun to wear with shorts or pleated trousers,” he explained. “It gives it a bit more character over your traditional boat shoe.” Timberland Timberland Adidas Adidas Ethan Glenn, TikTok’s reigning champ of elevated minimalism, is fully embracing slimmed-down footwear this summer. “I love wearing a slim loafer with no socks…the perfect casual shoe that can be dressed up so easily,” he said. He recommended the Morjas Ivy loafer and the Banana Republic’s moc-toe loafer. And for the more adventurous, a personal favorite of his:Lemaire’s square-toe loafers. When it comes to sneakers, Glenn only had one on his mind. “The shoe of the summer is the Dries Van Noten suede sneaker. Hands down,” he said. “I got my pair last fall and have worn them so much there’s a hole in the heel.” The brand’s ultra-slim runner—inspired by 1970s athletics, made from leather with suede trims—is a perfect specimen for the low-profile silhouette that is already dominating the men’s footwear conversation. While Glenn admits the slim rubber sole lacks the comfort and longevity of other sneakers, he still can’t stop wearing them. Because, as he put it: “Damn, they look good.” Morjas Morjas Dries Van Noten SSENSE Banana Republic Banana Republic Lemaire Nordstrom

title: ‘Hacks’ Season 4 Finale: Hannah Einbinder On Ava and Deborah's Boozy, Brutal Singapore Showdown
article_text: This article contains spoilers for theHacksseason four finale. By now the familiar pattern ofHacksseason finales are well established—a little predictable, even. The knife always gets twistedjustas we think Deborah (Jean Smart) and Ava (Hannah Einbinder) have established the terms of a ceasefire. But this season had a different rhythm to those before it, with the pair taking longer to make up after Ava blackmailed Deborah into making her head writer at the end of season three. By the time they fully reunited and celebrated creating the number one late-night show together, there wasn’t much road left. It seemed, for a moment, as though we had our classicHacksbetrayal cliffhanger in episode nine, with Deborah locking Ava out of the studio. But, in a genuine moment of surprise given the cruelty we’ve been conditioned to expect from Deborah, she instead gave Ava the big declaration of love she’s always needed. This puts the two of them in an uncomfortable new dynamic: Ava is now indebted to her boss, and Deborah, who has lost everything by sticking up for her, grows resentful and increasingly unhinged. In the whirlwind final episode, Deborah diverts their plane toSingaporeand expects Ava to smile along as she drinks her way through endless karaoke nights and falls asleep during her (translated) casino stand-up set. Ahead of the final episode airing, we spoke to Hannah Einbinder about shooting the finale’s chaotic montages, the heavy emotions in filming Deborah’s near-death experience, and that brutal confrontation. GQ: Let's go back a little first. The penultimate episode feels like the classicHackstwist, where we think Deborah is betraying Ava. How did you approach playing that knowing what was really coming? Hannah Einbinder:I’m very lucky that on this show the strength of the writing dictates a lot of my performance. Deborah is making this declaration of her love for Ava, she’s standing up to the network, which is so meaningful to her and so meaningful to me. It is this beautiful declaration of love and personal risk tied into one, and it’s moving. Whenever I heard that monologue in the table read I just could not stop myself from being pretty visibly emotional. Did it still feel emotional while you were filming that scene? I was in the security booth and I had [showrunner and co-creator] Paul [W. Downs] off-camera reading Deborah’s dialogue. He’s such an expressive, amazing actor, so hearing his voice definitely got me there. Were you surprised when reading the final episode? I was shocked. I couldn't have predicted the way that it ended up, but I love the place that they've left it. I think it's got a lot of momentum and it would lead to a brilliant fifth season. Deborah diverts the plane from their planned trip to Hawaii and you end up in Singapore. How was it filming there? It was wild, man. We were there for five days and it was my first time in Asia. I went to a really cool nature park that was a hike that led to a suspended bridge at the top of a rainforest. Frickin’ sick as hell. There’s a brutal conversation where Ava calls Deborah out on her drinking and general floundering after running away fromLos Angeles. Deborah responds by telling her she has no friends and has achieved nothing. Sobrutal—perhaps the meanest Deborah has ever been to her. It’s so devastating, Jean [Smart] is such a fucking good actress. The way she’s playing cruel drunk and also has her guard up, pretending she’s not wounded and at this rock bottom. It’s one of the all-time performances of that experience. I’m amazed by her at all times, but this scene was so brilliantly done. How do you and Jean Smart approach an intense or volatile scene like that? We're going on with our lives and talking normally, up until the moment action is called. We're so close that it's not nerve-wracking to yell at each other. The heated scenes are very fun for us to play. We don't do any of that method stuff. Near the end of the episode, Ava reads aTMZreport that Deborah has died and runs to her room. How was it reading the script not knowing what came next? I was sobbing. I at this point know that hopefully there is a fifth season ofHacks[which has been commissioned since this conversation took place] so that can't really hold, but as Ava I am sobbing because she thinks that's real. Did it feel that real to shoot it? Running up to the doorway thinking that she was dead was fucked up. I think in order to play that you have to go somewhere, just to make it look real. It's very frightening to imagine that and really horrible. That was very, very hard emotionally. Where do you think they end up at the end of this episode? There is this constant two steps forward, one step back with them, right? Deborah does this very grandiose declaration of solidarity with Ava. They go to Singapore, and she sort of descends into this alcoholic spell of darkness. I do think that their relationship has a toxicity to it and because of that they're able to just constantly forgive each other over and over. Do you think that there's a wound from some of the harsh stuff that Deborah said? I do think that will have to be reconciled. I don't know that it can be just glossed over. But Ava knows that Deborah is not herself when she's saying those things. She's just trying to hurt her, so I think that there's a little bit of understanding there. These are women whose mother-daughter dynamics are both very fraught. The bar is so low—Deborah and DJ, Ava and her mom—they don't have standards for healthy relationships in that way. Ava ends up using some of Deborah’s rulebook for this season and loses her way, do you think she’s finding herself again at the end? Ava's hands are sort of forced in the beginning to play by Deborah's rules because she's backed into a corner. I think she's trying throughout the season so desperately to hang on to her morals and convictions. When it comes to producing the actual show and the type of content that she wants the show to be, she's kind of constantly in this battle for not only herself, but for the two of them. Do you see a generational split in the way that fans of the show see Ava or Deborah? I do, but I know from what I hear talking to people is that this show has brought them together. People say, ‘my mom and I watch it together, my grandma and I watch it together, my daughter and I watch it together’. It really is not positioning one as being all knowing or one as being in the right at all times. There's value in both perspectives. It’s so funny that Deborah reading her inaccurateTMZobituary is what makes her so fired up to go back to work. Where would you like Ava to go in season 5? I am never able to nail any of the twists and turns of this show, like I have no idea. Jean and I asked to be kept out of it so that we can just come in fresh. They have only ever exceeded our expectations for the possibilities of this show and our characters. Do you think there might be a new location for them other than LA or Las Vegas? I would love that. I guess Deborah has a certain amount of months she can't perform or do anything, so they would have to do something else, unless there's a time jump. I feel like Ava deserves a healthy relationship. Don’t hold your breath, sweetheart! I ain’t holdin’ mine. This story originally appeared inBritish GQ.

title: Michael Cera, Who's Finally In a Wes Anderson Movie, Explains Why This Didn't Happen Sooner
article_text: Everyone online seems kind of shocked thatThe Phoenician Schememarks Michael Cera's first-ever appearance in aWes Anderson film. To be fair, it feels like a near-perfect match between an auteur and an actor both known for their peculiar quirks.Cerahas spent a career playing charmingly awkward social rejects, while “charmingly awkward”—in a slightly more bizarre, whimsical manner—tends to be a defining quality of Anderson's style. As Cera'sPhoenician Schemeco-starBenedict Cumberbatchput it: “Watching Wes Anderson discover and use Michael Cera is like God discovering water.” They could've worked together even sooner. At one point, Cera was down to play a role in Anderson'sAsteroid City, but the shoot dates got pushed back and ended up overlapping with his pregnant wife's due date. “I was like, There's no way I can come, because it was right around the time [my son] was going to be born,” Cera tellsGQ. “I didn't know if there would be another chance to work with Wes. I just was really glad that there was another opportunity.” Fortunately,The Phoenician Schemewas worth the wait. Cera plays Bjorn, a—yes—charmingly awkward Norwegian entomologist who is hired to tutor the children of Benicio del Toro's Zsa-Zsa Korda, a mega-rich industrialist whose latest scheme finds him in the crosshairs of rival businessmen, assassins, and his evil brother (played by Cumberbatch). Cera, with his cartoonish Norwegian accent and pinpoint comic timing, is the movie's most overt source of comic relief. We meet in a London hotel suite on a bright Thursday afternoon. He offers me a cookie as I sit— the last, lonely cookie on the plate—and looks somewhat crestfallen when I decline for reasons of pre-summer vanity. At the end of our conversation, he offers again. This time, I just can't turn him down. In the interim, Cera talks about being in his first Wes movie, finding Bjorn's zany accent, and reuniting with hisScott Pilgrimdirector Edgar Wright onThe Running Man. GQ: What had you heard about the experience of being in a Wes film? Michael Cera:Everybody says it's so much fun. And everybody says you basically live together, and it's very familiar—a personal, intimate experience. And it is! We all lived in a hotel in Potsdam, down the road from the studio, which was Studio Babelsberg, outside of Berlin. And basically, the production owns the hotel for the duration of the shoot. And then I think they have a certain date where it's like, “Okay, we've gotta get out of here, because the hotel's going to become open to the public again.” But, for the duration of the shoot, it [became] our hub. The offices are there. All the wardrobe is there, and the makeup; we'd get ready in the morning, get dressed, and then travel to set. And then at the end of the day we'd come home to the hotel, and have dinner. So that makes for a real kind of commune feeling – everybody's working together, and talking. There's so much trust, there's so much comfort and familiarity. Coming into it as a guest, you're included right away, and folded in. Have any of Wes' films been particularly impactful for you? I would say, as far as in my formative years [of] being a teenager, I was really obsessed withRushmore. I watched it countless times. I love the tone that it strikes, and I love the feeling, and the characters, and the music. The way that it's heartfelt, but in a very un-saccharine way. Really, it's like, Wes' language being kind of born in front of your eyes. What were your touchpoints when you were trying to find the accent? There were a couple. There were a few Scandinavian directors that I was watching videos of, that have a jaunty way of speaking. That's a Kenneth Mars performance inWhat's Up Doc?That was a big inspiration in a way, just the impact that this character has when he walks into the movie. That was sort of a North Star. I also read that Bjorn's little pair of glasses had prescription lenses. A very extreme prescription. The effect is that they demagnify your eyes. But looking through them, there's a huge distortion that happens. And then underneath them, I had to wear eye contacts which would work counter to the prescription, so that I could see clearly. The lenses were negative 12, and then I had contacts that were positive 12. But it doesn't equal a normal perspective. Everything is very warped, and you have no depth perception, but you can see things in sharp focus, whereas without the eye contacts, everything would be a big abstraction… There's a few shots in the movie where I was totally blind. There's a scene midway through when Bjorn jumps into quicksand and comes out caked. How was that makeup process? It took a while, but it was kind of a nice experience, in the end. It was sort of like getting a big facial. When you take it off, you feel reborn. [Laughs] We know that Wes likes to use the same actors. Have you had any conversations with him about being in another of his movies, yet? Well, I did a commercial with Wes this year, that we were acting together in, which was really fun. It was really great to be on screen with Wes. I think it's going to come out in June, or something. How is he as an actor? He is kind of an actor, in a way. I think he's a natural. A lot of the time, people are channeling him in his movies. A lot of the humor is just Wes, you know. Wes does these animatics of the movie before you shoot, and he's doing all the voices, and it gives you a little sense of the humor, and the taste, that he's going for with some of the lines. Not that you have to stick with the way he did it, and you should probably build on that, but it's a good start. It gives you a real handle on what the language of the movie is, in a way. You're making your directorial debut soon withLove is Not the Answer. Is there anything that you picked up from Wes? There's a lot. I would definitely feel like one [element of] watching him work that was striking is just that Wes will never move on from something unless it feels right. He would never settle. He would always push to get something right. It seems like a given, maybe, but it's amazing to watch someone work that way, with that level commitment to getting it right, and getting it the way he wants… Staying the course and charging toward it with that kind of conviction. Has directing long been an ambition? I would say so, yeah. But it was always about having the right material. I kind of never could find my way around directing a script that I hadn't built up, in one way or another. I had one or two opportunities over the years—I don't even know if these projects ever became fully realized—to consider directing other people's scripts. I don't know why. I never could figure it out. The thing is, this movie that I'm hoping to make this fall, it's just different when you write something, because you know what's behind every single intention along the way. You don't have to figure it out. It came from your idea, so you're connected to what it's supposed to mean and how it all adds up. Can you give any sense of what it's about? Well, not really what it's about. It's sort of hard to talk about… I guess the reason I want to make it is, I kind of want to make a movie that has its own language. And that's kind of the reason for me to make a movie, to try and find a voice… I mean, obviously, it's hard to make something that's totally not informed by all of the things that you've been inspired by, but that's to me what's exciting about it, trying to find a new, underexplored feeling, or tone, or language. And finally, how was it to reunite with Edgar Wright forThe Running Man? Edgar is really amazing, and I think that movie will be really fun. He showed me a little bit of a sizzle reel when I was there of what they'd shot. It looks cool. I think it's gonna be, like, a fun ride of a movie. Like a full, capital-M movie experience. You know, set piece after set piece. This story originally appeared inBritish GQ.

title: New Balance’s New Y2K-Inspired Sneakers Look Like a Sony MD Player For Your Feet
article_text: All products featured on GQ are independently selected by our editors. However, we may receive compensation from retailers and/or from purchases of products through these links. New Balancehas been enjoying a strong 2025—the stalwart sneaker brand has launchedhit grandpa-y silhouettes, linked up withthe hottest labels in fashion, and revived a handful oflong-beloved models. And thanks to the New Balance Abzorb 2000, things are only looking up. After months of teasers, the Boston sportswear brand’s next big sneaker is finally here. Borrowing a few moves from the 9060 silhouette (which has become the go-to shoe for very famous people likeMargot Robbie) the Abzorb 2000 is inspired by the kind ofretro runnersyou might find deep within New Balance’s archives. New Balance Abzorb 2000 ‘Blue Agate’ Working on top of a breezy mesh base, the shoe is overlaid by suede and synthetic panels to keep everything structured. An oversized “N” on the sides in silver keeps in line with the old-school vibe, and the OG “NB” logo is stamped on the tongue and heel. Down below, the chunky midsole comprises five giant Abzorb pods (the same tech that’s used on other bangers like the 1906R and992). It’s also fitted with a midfoot plate for added support. For its grand debut, the New England label opted for a ‘Blue Agate’ and ‘Still Water’ combo. And judging by what the lads onr/Newbalanceare saying, that was a solid choice. “I think they picked the perfect color to launch these with,” says one Redditor. “Having lived through the era this shoe is referencing, this exact shade of pearlescent baby blue is like a Sony MD player, a Winamp skin, a Baby Phat velourtracksuit.” Another simply said: “I will see this sneaker everywhere.” New Balance Abzorb 2000 ‘Blue Agate’ Set to drop on June 14, the New Balance Abzorb 2000 ‘Blue Agate’ will be available viaNew Balanceand select stockists worldwide for $165. More colorways are coming soon, including the neon pink ‘Dragon Berry’ and an icy white version. New Balance Abzorb 2000 ‘Blue Agate’ This story originally appeared onBritish GQ.

title: Clipse Talk Love, Hate, and What Rap’s Been Missing
article_text: This story was featured in The Must Read, a newsletter in which our editors recommend one can’t-miss story every weekday.Sign up here to get it in your inbox. Pusha T and Maliceare bored. It’s gray, rainy, and much colder than it should be on this mid-May afternoon in Manhattan, and the brothers—known to family and friends as Terrence and Gene, and to the music industry as the formidable Virginia rap duo Clipse—are lounging in a Mercedes sprinter dodging raindrops, killing time. But that stormy mood extends to their overall opinion about the rap game at large right now. The particulars of the casual conversation we’re having are off the record, but the overall sentiment is one they’ll formally reiterate to me later: They are not impressed. “I'm a passive listener to things that are going on right now,” Pusha says. “You got tograbme, man.” On Pusha T:Jacket and sneakers by Louis Vuitton Men's. T-shirt by Lemaire. Pants by Enfants Riches Déprimés. Hat and jewelry, (throughout) his own.On Malice:Jacket by Simone Rocha. T-shirt and jeans, by Lemaire. Sneakers by Louis Vuitton Men's. Jewelry (throughout), his own. Mainstream rap music has been something of a desert lately, I concede, and Pusha agrees, before impishly throwing a rhetorical question back to me: “Why is that?” He has no answer to share himself, maybe because for him and his older brother, the whys don’t matter: At this particular moment, the lane is wide open for one of the genre’s most beloved groups to deliver a reunion 16 years in the making—and raise the standard as they’ve always done. But after years of dancing around the idea—loosie Clipse tracks here and there sprinkled across the past five years, a return to performing festival shows together, and a protracted album rollout that began in earnest on the runway of longtime collaborator Pharrell Williams’sinaugural showas creative director of Louis Vuitton—it feels like we probably should’ve had the long-awaited fourth Clipse album about a year ago at this point. But this summer, Malice and Pusha swear, it’s finally go time. “Once you've delivered and once you have done your part, you got to see how things fall in place,” Malice says sagely. “And a lot of times they fall in place better than you could have planned.” Now, with the release of a disgusting first official single in “Ace Trumpets,” the self-proclaimed pioneers of Coke Rap are ready to roll out the white carpet, explain their delays and their recommitment to each other, and above all else, reaffirm why they are not to be doubted—or fucked with. Pusha and Maliceare eager to talk—but first and foremost, they’re eager toeat.Dressed inadvertently in yin-and-yang fits—Pusha in an all-black sweatsuit, Malice wearing the same in gray—they decamp from the sprinter for an early dinner, only to experience what may or may not have been a racial microaggression from the hostess at Hillstone. Now we’re cruising downtown aimlessly, looking for a top-tier meal at the awkward time of 4:30 p.m. on a weekday. Pusha grows more dejected and annoyed by the block; he’d been looking forward to that Hillstone spinach dip all day. Clocking that we’re now approaching Houston, I throw out a Hail Mary: Emilio’s Ballato. The Italian restaurant has been a Nolita staple for decades and has become especially trendy in the past few years, but more importantly it’s been a personal favorite of my family in particular since the late ’90s. Pusha is unfamiliar but curious—especially when their driver Mike decides to raise the stakes, comparing it favorably to Carbone. “Okay, now thisbetterbe good,” Pusha declares. That’s a tall order from a guy who’s spent the last 20-odd years disdainfully rapping about having better taste than you—his last album has anartfully constructed Breitling put-downso sneeringly rhymed that you’d think he was talking about a Swatch. A standout offering among the new Clipse music features him rhyming “Audi” with “au pair”—as in, the only reason that particular brand of German-engineered auto is on his residential premises is because it’s driven by his four-year-old son’s nanny. Meeting, raising, and exceeding the standard has been Clipse’s raison d’etre at least as far back as their sophomore album,Hell Hath No Fury,a Neptunes-scored Coke Rap fantasia adored by white hipster critics, SoHo cool kids, those who could actually relate to Push and Malice’s subject matter, and everyone in between. Two decades removed from that classic, the Thornton brothers acknowledge that legacy and past accomplishments are cool but insist they wouldn’t have come back together if they were content with chasing old highs; the pursuit of greatness is neverending. If every new thing you create doesn’t reinforce your place in the conversation amongst the best to ever do it, then why bother? “I feel like I had seen the engine [give] out on rap,” Malice says. “Besides my brother and a couple others, I feel like it's in the same place it was when I left.” Pusha cites the wily Griselda rapper Stove God Cooks, who appears on the album, as a favorite, and agrees with his brother that Future is always on time, but asked if there’s anything else around that’s exciting him he responds with a hilariously emphatic, resolute “No.” “We've never given mediocre. I hear so much music, and it's just like an assembly line—and it works, they sell it, and people eat it up,” Malice says with a shrug. “But it's an art that I always find that's missing and I feel like we always give that. We always have delivered that.” It’s fascinating to hear Malice’s thoughts on the rap game at large right now, because for the past decade and change, he’s been a passive observer. For a while there, the elder Thornton brother was on the list of rap’s greatest self-exiles. Throughout the aughts, Malice and Pusha put Virginia Beach on the map over upper-echelon production from their fellow VA natives and adolescent friends turned superproducers Pharrell Williams and Chad Hugo, a.k.a. the Neptunes. The raps—mostly about selling drugs—were vivid, intricate yet accessible, the flexes felt lived-in yet next-level, delivered with such authority that you couldn’t dare question their validity. But by the turn of the next decade, Malice opted to end their family affair—at least on wax. The Thorntons maintain that in real life, their brotherhood continued unwaveringly. But musically, Malice was burnt out, experiencing a crisis of faith and purpose. You know the rest: Pusha soldiered on solo at the same time Kanye West’s GOOD Music crew became ascendant, quickly becoming a key piece in that squad all while sharpening his powers and aesthetics to produce some of the most finely crafted mainstream drug-rap of the 2010s, while Malice explored religion, wrote books, and penned non-secular bars with a pointed addendum to his stage name: No Malice. That is until 2019—the turn of another decade, and another change of heart. During sessions at his Wyoming ranch for what would become hisJesus Is Kingalbum, Kanye asked Pusha for Malice’s number; Pusha was in the early throes of a disillusionment with what it meant to be in Kanye’s orbit—“living through the foolishness,” as he describes it—even though their union would sustain for another two or three years (more on that later). “I don't want to bring him into the foolishness,” Pusha recalls thinking. Malice affirms: “He was like, ‘You don't want to do this.’” Still, Malice gave his blessing and ended up coming out to Wyoming with his brother. “I don't deal with foolishness at all,” Malice says with a smirk. “But I saw what he was talking about.” As frustrating as the experience ultimately was, it served as a crucial spark for the reunion. It yielded the first official new Clipse track in “Use This Gospel,” but the sessions were even more fruitful than fans realized. The brothers haverevealedthey wrote to the “Follow God” beat before Kanye snatched it back forJesus is King;ironically, being so productive made Pusha more frustrated, since the stuff they were creating together was still stuck under Kanye’s umbrella. “I feel like we were [suddenly] convinced that it could happen,” Push says of their first reunion thoughts. “But there was so much going on within the whole Ye circle…. If we decided we were going to jump into it, then we should be jumping into it. It wasn't progressing like that. So, I think, if anything, that was a stumble on just trying to make it happen and everybody not just being on the same time schedule. That was bothersome to me.” Still, more loosie tracks here and there laid the breadcrumbs, including the stellar Malice guest verse that closed Pusha’s most recent solo album in 2022. “I ain’t miss no step,” Malice says playfully but with conviction when I ask about getting back into the swing of things in those years. “I don’t do that.” Kanye produced that song, but his and Pusha’s relationship wouldn’t hold for much longer. Which is too bad for rap fans whoremember the Rosewood Movementfondly; but on the other hand, there’s something extra poetic about the three-way reunion that the Thornton brothers linking on an album entirely produced by Pharrell represents. (In the wake of a falling-out between P and Chad Hugo, the Neptunes are no more; on the new music Malice raps “Ain’t no more Neptunes, so P’s Saturn.”) If there’s anyone who understands the power in not looking back and shedding legacy, it’s Pharrell, who’s lately taken to auctioning off the old jewelry from his Neptunes/NERD peaks that most would consider holy grails (more on that later too). “Locking in with P is good because we revert back to very fanned-out times of ourselves,” Pusha says. “It ain't about like,Oh, that songorthat beat was knocking. But the feeling. Like,Man, we got to make people feel like this. But how do we evoke that feeling? Oh, maybe that beat is evoking a feeling that we ain't felt in a minute. Or the raps or these flows. But it's always about really trying to dial into the emotion of the song. And I think that's the fun part about it because that's where we get to really feel and find that newness in rapping.” The result isLet God Sort Em Out. Longtime fans worried about the Thorntons recapturing the magic can rest easy. The project simultaneously stokes an old familiarity, starting with the title, which continues the religious theme set byLord Willin’andHell Hath No Fury—and, as Malice points out, even their unofficial debut project from the days when Pusha still went by “Terror,”Exclusive Audio Footage, started with a prayer. But in true Clipse fashion, the title cuts both ways, working on one hand as a declaration of faith, and on the other as an extreme declaration of aggression. After all, how’s the full phrase most commonly associated with that title go?Kill ’em all…. The Thorntonshave their orders settled: Shrimp with spicy marinara and linguine for Malice, fra diavolo for Pusha. But before we even crack open a menu, the Emilio’s decor—pictures of the owner with one-name legends who’ve graced his tables, like Denzel, Leo, Lenny, and Rihanna—has set their wariness at ease. “I’ve been alone at this for a long time,” Pusha says, tearing into a basket of focaccia bread. “[During] that whole time, what you miss the most is that level of camaraderie and undying loyalty.” Pusha’s solo tenure was one marked by high highs, at least one critically agreed-upon classic album…and a whole lot of what he describes as “industry games.” So finally standing side by side with his older brother again has been, he says, a “breath of fresh air.” As far as Malice is concerned, he’s coming back not a moment too soon. In conversation, getting back into the noncreative swing of things like photoshoots and interviews, he shows no sign of rust or discomfort—he listens with a sage patience, replying to most questions with a twinkle in his eye that offsets Pusha’s doggedness. He’s well-rested and eager to apply what he’s learned—about himself, and about the way the industry can wear artists down—to this new era. “It was an awesome learning experience for me to be removed and to look at everything that I’ve experienced, the good and the bad. God has sat me down, and I spent time reading his words,” Malice says. Stepping back made it easier to see how his peers and those who came afterward found themselves on wayward paths. “I can identify the problems, and you see all of the turmoil and the issues of life, you see people going to jail. I'm talking about rappers, strung out on drugs, feeling the need to talk back to their fans. You see people's ego taking them left and taking them right, and you can just tell they have never learned to just sit down…. You can rise above that internally if you are at peace with yourself. You don't have to address everything. So, I learned a lot about myself in that downtime. And I am definitely all the better for it.” As Malice soul-searched, he cheered Pusha on from the sidelines. “I absolutely missed being with my brother. I always kept up with him, watched how he was moving and saw what he has to deal with out here. I always kept up with him, so I could know how to pray over him.” But Malice says he never felt any guilt about doing what he needed to do, or that he was abandoning his brother to face challenges he couldn’t handle. “I was never surprised by his success. I always expected it, anticipated it. I knew who he was when we were together. So, when he took off, it was like that's how I always saw my brother. I knew he could do it.I knew.I never had a doubt.” While the brothers admit it took a minute before they felt they were fully creating at a level close to the standard fans expect, a shared desire to elevate or else kept them locked in from the start. “We can't play on any level—you got to go through the trial-and-error of it all. You know what I'm saying?” Pusha says. “Just respecting the sense of urgency—think about it. We all have our lives.” He needn’t say more to explain what he’s referencing: his first child, still a toddler; Gene’s own family; and Pharrell’s family and day job running Louis Vuitton from the Paris headquarters, where a majority of the album was recorded in a feat of multitasking. “At the end of the day,” he says, “the music has to sound as urgent as if we had nothing. It's like records can begood,but that's not it. Yeah, that'shard,but that don't make it. And it's all because we recognize the standard and the standard that I feel like people are holding us to.” That means no resting on the laurels of reunion vibes, running back plays that worked before, listening toHell Hathand the like for inspiration. Malice doesn’t even want you to get them fucked up thinking the title is an attempt to stoke nostalgia. “Well, you say it's like a comeback title, but we never want to present it likewe're back,” Malice explains. “No matter the day and the age, you just have to deliver. We do what we do. It's always quality. Everything is always fine-tuned. We could never just give you haphazard. And I think that's what the fans recognize about us. They know that everything that we do is chiseled and handcrafted.” Let God Sort Em Outis worth the wait. True to his word, Malice hasn’t missed a step, Pusha is right there with him, and the production—spare, synthy and hard-hitting—is the most locked-in Pharrell has sounded in years; it wouldn’t truly be a Clipse reunion without P hoarding his best beats for Terrence and Gene. But the idea of Pharrell crafting beats like the rugged centerpiece “Mike Tyson” or mixing a Stove Good hook down a hallway from Parisian designers sewing jackets provides an extra thrill. However long it took to get back in sync,LGSEOsounds like it could’ve come just years after ’09’sTil the Casket Drops—and it’s easily better than that album, which both brothers have long admitted is their weakest effort—the way they have settled back into their complementary roles: Pusha the snarling tactician, Malice the wise and wary warrior. And still, there’s innovation. Pusha has long acknowledged the common critical assessment that Malice’s verses usually have more emotional substance to them. “I really dabbled with that criticism in my solo career a lot,” Pusha admits. “And [eventually] I gave up. I can only be who I am. And I used to [try to] be conscious of that—what people might be missing from what they got from the Clipse and I tried to make twists and turns through [my] verses. But, it only works one way for you, man.” The purest version of you, is you. “Yeah, and that's it.And that's it. But listen, I heard those comments. I heard them. And every time, I felt like, damn, they just miss Gene.” But the new album charts interesting evolutions for both brothers. Listen closely and you’ll hear Pusha casually revealing woes and tribulations within his own immediate family, or that he still longs to “kiss Mama’s cheek—I miss it.” The wrenching “Birds Don’t Sing,” which sees each brother dedicating a verse to one of their recently departed parents, started with Pusha. They decided it had to start the album to set a proper tone: that this project will not be exactly what you might expect to hear from the Clipse. Meanwhile, where the original-run Clipse albums showed Malice becoming increasingly weary, time off and to himself finds him sounding more renewed than ever, more than happy to pop shit as savagely as his brother. “First of all, the time that I took off was necessary,” Malice says. “I don't regret that at all. But I didn't want to squander my real estate in this little piece of what I have to offer, what I have to say in my contribution. I think it was meant for me to sit down for the time that I did, but I think now is the perfect time just to give my contribution to hip-hop.” The other longstanding critical Clipse opinion: that Malice is simply the sharper of the two, something Pusha has always been unbothered by, even once rapping: “Say my brother better? Big deal…second fiddle to my own gene pool/We laugh about it, that's cool/I'm at the top and he better? If you think about it, we rule.” “You tell me,” Pusha says with a laugh when asked who’s rapping better on the new stuff, sharing that their friend Mike Camargo told him, “‘He’s sounding better than you on 80% of this.’ I mean, people are saying it. And I can't wait for everyone to hear it, because I feel like they're really going to appreciate the actual duo of us whether you’re a new or old fan.” Malice is smirking to Pusha’s left as he says this; the brothers are clearly fans of each other first and foremost. The only person who missed hearing Malice spit like this more than rap fans of a certain age was Pusha himself. Malice points to “POV,” a slow-tempo that finds Pusha ratcheting up that disdainful, disaffected talk-flow he favors sometimes to obscene levels as his favorite Terrence verse on the project, while Pusha selects “FICO,” a boisterous track featuring Stove God Cooks on the hook, as his Gene pick. But tellingly, both brothers point to the new single, “Ace Trumpets,” as their favorite song overall. The least busy beat, and the least high-concept conceit: just hard 808s and hard flexes, i.e., Malice rapping “Never leave the house without my piece like I’m Mahatma.” “I find pleasure in that,” Push says. In just talking your shit? “Yeah, man, because I think that's what it's about. It's stunting. But it still shows that there's a technique and a style to it.” “I feel like these are the things missing in rap and why it's so disposable,” Malice adds. “Shit like this, the stickiness of records like that and verses like that is what keeps this going and what keeps rap around—good rap around.” Still,it wouldn’t be a Clipse album without some label woes nearly derailing the fun even after the product was cooked to purity. The duo’s lore is, of course, marked by the label politics that delayed a quick follow-up to their debut album,Lord Willin’,forcing them to dominate the mixtape circuit with their seminalWe Got It 4 Cheapseries while craftingHell Hath No Furywith a chip on their shoulder. What happened withLet God Sort Em Outis less dramatic, but it’s a situation with massive reverberations nonetheless. If you expected the album last summer, the brothers sympathize—so did they. Pusha says they felt confident, proud, and assured of themselves when they presented the music to Def Jam. The label loved what they heard—except for Kendrick Lamar’s guest verse on the thunderous “Chains & Whips,” the final version of the song that Pharrell teased at his first LV runway show, and the song Pusha says was the first to come out of their sessions. Don’t be fooled by Pusha’s interviews appealing for one last guest verse and the Twitter jokes that he went to a GNX Tour date to physically walk Kendrick into the nearest studio; K. Dot’s verse homework has been turned in for a while now. But after a summer of beef between their two biggest artists that resulted in a still ongoing lawsuit from Drake, Def Jam’s parent company UMG blanched at the antagonistic opp-optics of two of Drake’s biggest enemies linking on wax. Pusha calls their apprehension “stupid”—primarily because none of the bars in Kendrick’s otherwise excellent verse could really be perceived as a shot or even subliminal. (It does, however, contain the stellar line: “Therapy taught me how to open up/It also showed me I don’t give a fuck.”) Pusha can barely contain his disgust recounting how the stalemate with Def Jam played out. “They wanted me to ask Kendrick to censor his verse, which of course I was never doing,” he explains. “And then they wanted me to take the record off. And so, after a month of not doing it, Steve Gawley, the lawyer over there, was like, ‘We'll just drop the Clipse.’ But that can't work because I'm still there [solo]. But [if] you let us all go….” Sure enough, Def Jam eventually agreed to release the Clipseanddrop Pusha as a solo artist, freeing the duo up to shop for a new home with a finished Clipse album and “plenty more music” in their pockets. Ultimately, Pusha says, the endeavor was gratifying: “It felt good to even see how other labels were buying for the project.” Now—as they teased last week, with a picture in front of the label’s plane insignia—they’ve ended up at Jay-Z’s Roc Nation, where they feel fully supported and energized. “I think that that synergy, just in a rap sense, is going to speak volumes,” Pusha says of the partnership. So if they’re now officially doing business with the Roc, and the Kendrick verse was never the feature Pusha kept alluding to holding out for…does this mean we’re due for another Pusha and Jay-Z collaboration? (Pusha’s already gottena latter-career best from Jay—one can only imagine how hard Jigga would go for his first true-blue Clipse collab.) “We made history a couple of times,” Push says with a coy smirk, referring to the two elusive Jay features he’s nabbed in the past. “I feel like being in business is a bigger link up than any verse.” Asked if Jay made his patented screwface when he heard the new music, Pusha replies, “Yeah, but you got that on camera already,” referring to crowd shots of Jay reacting to “Chains & Whips” during the LV show. Ironically, if anybody deserves a speeding ticket for antagonizing other rappers on “Chains,” it’s Pusha, whose verse is a not so thinly veiled response to veteran Dipset rapper Jim Jones going on something of a “what’s the big deal about Pusha T” tour during a run of interviews debating the top 50 MCs of all-time. “I personally never understood what the interviews were about,” Pusha says. “Or why my name kept coming up. It's one thing to keep saying I'm not a top 50 MC, but it's another thing for you not to say that you [yourself] are one. No one asked me about a Top 50 nothing. After about the third interview, I promise you, I said,Man, he must really want me to know what he thinks about me.And that's how [my] verse came. This is what I really think about him. This is what Ireally think about him. Every line is my true heart.” Listen closely elsewhere on the album and you’ll find at least one other instance of Pusha letting another rapper knowwhat he really thinks about them,sounding as menacing yet unbothered as ever. I ask Malice, who doesn’t appear to have any personal problems with anyone, what’s going through his mind when he sees his younger brother get into demon mode like this. “He's being true to himself,” Malice says, uncorking the heartiest chuckle he’s let out all day. “This is who I knew him to be growing up—and it gets worse.” Jones wasted no time responding to the song’s tease with his own freestyle over the beat, but this was two springs ago at this point. Now that the song’s being released officially, if Capo has more to say, Pusha isn’t sweating it—nor does he seem particularly impressed by the initial reply. “Hey, man, listen,” he says with an evil smile, “He can do whatever he wants.” One foe who definitely isn’t getting any (more) of Pusha’s time at press time, though? Drake. The 6ix God famously bowed out of their 2018 Memorial Day Weekend bout just as it was getting good, when Pusha forever altered the perception of diss tracks by backing his up with forensic evidence like a legal investigator. Drake infamously let things fizzle out before dropping an album with lines like “Never a matter ofcould Iorshould I…. As luck would have it, I've settled into my role as the good guy.” But before the events of last spring, Drake had been spending a lot of time on wax practically begging Pusha to get back in the ring—particularly in 2023, when he madea music videowearing all of the classic Pharrell jewelry pieces that P auctioned off in (intentionally?) swagless fashion; bragged, on Travis Scott’s “Meltdown,” that he would destroy those grails without a care; and claimed that he could post up in Virginia any time on his ownFor All the Dogsalbum, where he also taunted a rapper going broke amidst a refrain of“empty clips.”In the years since they battled, Drake has done everything to complicate the good-guy image he once gamely upheld—Dogseven samples theScarface“bad guy” clip. Pusha’s heard the taunts, and much like when I asked hima similar question three years ago, he could not care less. “I think after everything that had been done, I don't think there was ever anything subliminal to be said ever again in life. Not only just musically, like bro, I actually wasinCanada. I actually had a show andmade it home.So, I can't pay attention to none of that. I did the dance for real, not to come back and tip-toe around anything.” So, you would only ever engage again if he went full tilt? “Man, I would only engage againif I felt like it.” So for the record, bait-jobs like buying and wearing Neptunes pieces from the same era that Clipse thrived in aren’t going to do the trick. “He’s always said he was a fan. So I feel like that's something a fan would do. It wasn't like [P] was hurting for money and sold his jewelry,” Pusha says with a dismissive laugh, referring to the chains Drake “boughtat an auction.” Still, however assured Pusha feels in his own battles with Drake, I’ve wondered if it feels bittersweet to him in any way that Kendrick got the full back-and-forth knockout experience, whereas his was in a way cut short by label interference, J. Prince weighing in, and Drake ultimately backing away. “Nah, I feel like everything happened the way it was supposed to happen,” Pusha says. “I had my own vision and my own intent in everything that I did during that time. And I did everything I wanted to do. There was nothing that I felt slighted about in watching anything [last year]. It was good to watch. I knew where it was going, I knew how it was going to play out. And it did.” Earlier, when discussing Def Jam clutching their pearls over a Clipse-Kendrick record, Pusha said it all “reminded him too much of 2018.” Weighing in on Drake's and Kendrick’s ongoing feud—namely, Drake’s decision to sue UMG over releasing “Not Like Us”—Pusha elaborates on what he meant. “I will say this,” Pusha shares, admitting he’s no bar-approved counselor with intimate knowledge of the suit. “If [Drake’s] adamant to have a lawsuit, it's only because he knows all the things that they did to suppress everything that was happening around ‘Adidon’ and the verses and the records and things that were happening back then.” He alludes to instances in which, he says, label machinations muddled if not outright nixed the release of verses in which Pusha talked his shit next to people closely affiliated with Drake, as he did on Rick Ross and Lil Wayne’s “Maybach Music VI” and a posthumously released Pop Smoke song with Young Thug. “I don't rate him no more,” Pusha says of Drake’s off-wax antics. “The suing thing is bigger than some rap shit. I just don't rate you. Damn, it's like it just kind of cheapens the art of it once we gotta have real questions about suing and litigation. Like, what? Forthis?” Pusha once rapped that he’s often “at the mercy of a game where the codes is missing”; as our conversation turned toward beefs, disagreements, and conflicts, he seemed to want to go out of his way to reject the idea of him being a bully. The way he sees it, every heat check or headshot he’s doled out has been the product of him finishing energy that others started. “I've really been in Paris, making my joints, doing my shit. When these people mention me, they're really going out of their way,” Pusha says. “What have I done besides wear clothes these past couple of years? I just been with LV. This shit ain't coming out of nowhere. Bro, I be cool with all these guys. Everybody you mentioned today, bro, I promise you,theydid the underhanded, weird shit.” Weird shit that you won’t hear him dedicate any energy to in music any time soon? His falling out with Kanye. While they’ve quite clearly gone their separate ways at this point, Pusha says things were headed there and the last few months or years of his time with Kanye were him “playing the industry game” more than anything. “I realized at certain points that I was really alone in everything that was going on as far as rap drama, so on and so forth,” Push recalls. He points to the 2021Dondasessions in Atlanta as one of those points. “I'm in a collective of a lot of individuals. Everybody's working, but I really got shit to do, and I leave and it's one energy, and then when I come back, the energy's off. And then you hear about the sidebar conversations. You got your homeboy who coming up to you like, ‘Yo, they was saying this when you left.’ I'm thinking that we all in this collectively getting busy. But in all actuality, everybody had their own agendas. And I feel like I was the only one who didn't. My agenda was for the squad. So from that point on, I just looked at everybody differently, and I looked at it as,We're just going to make music. We're going to get beats. We're going to write some raps. And we going to keep it moving." At press time, Kanye has burned virtually nearly every bridge and collaborative relationship he’s ever had, and Pusha is no exception. “It's like, bro, you've been mentioning me, screaming about me…. You got every soul believing that I've done such a great injustice to you. And that's a lie. He goes on his rants. The one thing that I can say about him is that he knows that every issue that he's having and crying about online right now, I've told him distinctly about those things, distinctly. So when he gets up there and with his KKK mask and he's screaming behind it like a pro wrestler—he got to scream behind a mask. He don'ttalkto me like he talks to others.” It’s usually invigorating to hear Pusha talk his shit, but there’s something sad about seeing such a prolific partnership end like this. “We made some great shit, bro. We did,” Pusha acknowledges. “But…let me tell you something. He's a genius. And his intuition is even more genius level, right? But that's why me and him don't get along, because he sees through my fakeness with him. He knows I don't think he’s a man.He knows it.And that's why we can't build with each other no more. That's why me and him don't click, because he knows what I really,reallythink of him. He's showed me the weakest sides of him, and he knows how I think of weak people.” More important to Pusha than the music he made with Kanye is how Kanye handled the financial fruits of that relationship. Five years ago, after publicly expressing frustration with the predatory nature of label deals in general and the splits on his Def Jam contract in particular, Ye announced that he planned to give his 50% ownership stake in the masters of his own GOOD Music roster back to the artists themselves; today, Pusha says West kept his word. “The greatest thing he did and why I am okay with where me and him are right now—and I'm cool with staying that way—is because at the end of the day, my truth is my truth, but I still respect what he did in the business. And he speaks ill about the music we've made and giving me certain records, but the one thing he did give me was all the profits back from the Def Jam deal.” When it comes to Kanye, there’s always the question of how much of his erratic behavior can be attributed to the mental-health issues he’s openly discussed. To what degree can you truly hold his rants and screeds against him? “He's sick, I do believe that much. You're sick, but you're also very calculated. And if I take your sickness and take how calculated you've been and disruptive you've been and tried to be to me, then it cancels itself out. I can't look at it as sick, because you're detrimental. You're detrimental to everything.” Industry games, politics, fake allegiances—they all underscore how important it is to Pusha to have his brother back with him navigating shark-infested waters. “Bro, listen, that's been the biggest comfort and the biggest asset to me,” Pusha says, impassioned. “You got to understand, where I'm from, we build that loyalty amongst friends; once we lock in as a crew, this is how it goes. We together. And we win together, we lose together. This is how we go. “All of [this other stuff] was new to me, but it got to a point where it got dangerous. And that's where I felt like I had to remove myself. You got all these different snaky people and all these agenda-having people around. People backbiting you—come on, man. It's been really crazy. But ultimately, the Clipse album for me was a departure and just something that I missed and just…brotherhood. You know what I'm saying? It's like damn, bro. Shit was therapy for so many reasons, but most importantly, like damn…just natural, genuine brotherhood.” The plates have been cleared, my taste reputation with the brothers remains intact, and if Emilio hadn’t been handling a disturbance in the kitchen, there might have been a new photo to put on the Ballato wall. Pusha and Malice are content in the moment, but in conversation, sounding renewed overall. Is it right to say this reunion feels less like a one-off and more like the start of a new run? “I believe that. I think the energy is going to speak for itself, and I think the people are going to keep calling for it,” Pusha says. For once today, Malice is the Thornton brother to flash a devilish grin, looking to the ceiling to avoid making any eye contact. “I believe what he believes,” Malice says with a smile. On Pusha T: Jacket, shorts, and sneakers, by Louis Vuitton Men's. T-shirt by Lemaire. Socks, his own.On Malice:Jacket and sneakers by Louis Vuitton Men's. T-shirt by Dries Van Noten. Jeans by Simone Rocha. But even if Malice is hesitant to commit formally, I thought back to something the brothers said earlier, about competing in the game even as Pusha nears 50 and his older brother stares down 53. “Rap don't age out,” Pusha said. “As long as you're of the culture and you're in it and you're competing, you don't ever have to age out. What you mean?” Malice agrees: “You either have something to offer or you don't. I don't think it's an age limit on this at all. Either you got it or you don't.” And if the mantra and the results behindLet God Sort Em Outare any indication, the Thorntons aren’t lacking for competitive spirit. They’re here to kill ‘em all. Pusha nods in affirmation. “Every time.” PRODUCTION CREDITS:Photographs byEric JohnsonGrooming byBarry WhiteSpecial thanks toMarcus Paul, personal stylist to Clipse

title: Intrepid “Journalist” Jessica Reed Kraus, aka HouseInhabit, Is Going to “Report” the Idaho Murders Trial
article_text: Well, we can’t say thatJessica Reed Krausdoesn’t keep us guessing. Is she a journalist? A blogger? A busy mom with apassion for negging womenwho accuse men of sexual abuse? Dedicated #spon poster for colostrum powder? Aconservative PAC staffer, or—wait, was that amember of the White House press corps? The identity that Kraus Inhabits seems to depends on the angle of the sun and whetherRobert F. Kennedy Jr.is acknowledging her that day, but in a slew of Instagram Stories throughout the weekend, Kraus revealed that she’s heading to Idaho in August to “report” on the trial ofBryan Kohberger, who stands accused of murdering four University of Idaho students in 2022, as only she can. (A judge entered a not-guilty plea on Kohberger's behalf.) The trial begins in Moscow, Idaho, on August 11. Kraus built her following on Instagram and then Substack throughchronicling celebrity court caseslike the defamation suits betweenAmber HeardandJohnny Depp,which settled in 2022. More recently, she pivoted to politics, fixating on all things MAHA, and now she’s once again pirouetting back to celebrity, spitting out takes that evoke a sort of TMZ-meets-opium-den vibe. You never know what the takes willbe, but you do know they’re going to be baffling. In May, Kraus said on her Stories that she wasn’t covering theDiddytrial because she’d “rather be in unchecked corners where other media isn’t” and that she’s “always attracted to where media interest isn’t.” (Shedevoted multiplenewslettersto covering the trial, while also whining via Stories that she was having a tough time because the music is so important to her.) Naturally,she’s already complainingabout “how competitive it is already” among media who plan to cover the trial, based on a Zoom she sat in on in late May. “Tensions flared over courtroom access and who should get what once the trial starts,” Kraus wrote in her newsletter (the “truly, the best eight dollars you can spend each month,” according to a Story she posted over the weekend) on May 29. “Someone from mainstream press argued that credentialed outlets deserved priority, implying thatus ‘internet sleuths and conspiracy theorists’shouldn’t be treated as equals. But the judge reiterated that access will be granted on a first-come, first-serve basis through reservations. I fear it’s going to be a full-fledged media circus on that lot come August.” Ah, yes, the corners of a high-profile quadruple murder trial. So unchecked. Her daily barrage of social media posts is an ever-rotating sampler platter of a very specific Weird Internet cuisine: Recently, she's started reading the Bible, and has suggested that she start a “HIH Bible Study.” She spent a few days on a military boat during Fleet Week, where former press secretarySean Spicerposted multiple photos of her just…horizontal on the deck. Chillin’. Recently, there was a string of Instagram Stories aboutJoe Bidenpossibly being…a clone? And promises of a list of, let me just check my notes to make sure I have this right, yes, the “10 sexiest men in the 119th Congress.” Shealsorecently shared photos of her husband installing a fully stocked bar, complete with uplighting, in her home office. (Remember when she was justso busyin the White House that she was considering renting out an apartment in the District?) So, like, kind of anyone’s call whether this hack of all trades will spud her way to the Gem State come August. Recently, she posted that readers had expressed interest in a broader variety of topics from her post-election, which sounds like she got called out for not actually knowing much about politics in the first place. (Remember when she eavesdropped on some guy on a bus talking about tariffs and then published a“tariffs for dummies” primerbased on that? This is the authority we crave in the age of disinformation.) To quote Kraus herself: More later. title: How Lilly Pulitzer Brought Palm Beach Style to the Masses
article_text: Lilly Pulitzerwas the queen of colorful and playful, perhaps a bit childish, style in Palm Beach, Florida. Her shift dresses marked an era, and from 1958, the year she founded her brand, to the present day they continue to be beloved in the favorite vacation spots of the elite. The very ones in which the plot ofSirens, the NetflixTV seriesdirected byMolly Smith Metzlerand starringJulianne Moore, Kevin Bacon, Milly AlcockandMeghann Fahy. The plot is as mysterious as it is fascinating, and everything is extremely polished, starting with the wardrobe of the main characters. Who, unlike Devon, the black sheep of the group played by Fahy, wear colorful, patterned mini-dresses that look like something out of a dollhouse. "I spent a summer in Martha’s Vineyard and I’ve since spent some summers in Nantucket," Metzler toldVariety. "My best friend has a house there, and it’s for real. Lilly Pulitzer is for real. They all have it on in Nantucket. Then there’s the Nantucket reds, the salmon color pants. The first time you see it, you’re like, 'Where am I?' It’s so bright. It’s sort of like, if you’ve been there, you’re in on the joke, you know the pants to buy." Lilly Pulitzer in Palm Beach in 1961. In 1958, newly married and in her early twenties, Pulitzer moved to Palm Beach with her toddler daughter and her husband, a descendant of the family that created the prestigious literary prize and wealthy citrus orchard owner. Brilliant and a maverick, unable to sit idly by and simply enjoy the family's immense fortune, she sets up a small fruit store where she also served freshly squeezed juices and ended up staining herself all the time. So she decides to create a dress with a print that can disguise the splashes with the help of artist and textile designer Suzie Zuzek, who created the intricate patterns that became the brand's signature. Women in Palm Beach wear garments designed by Lilly Pulitzer in 1964. The New York-origin socialite is a decidedly atypical character for the high society to which she belongs. Liberal and progressive, she likes to enjoy life, walk barefoot and has a style all her own. "The first designs I made in the beginning were made from fabrics I bought in cheap stores in West Palm Beach. When they debuted, they were a real shock to everyone: they thought they would last one season and then disappear, but the opposite happened," she recounted in 1971 in aninterviewgiven to the Palm Beach Post. Pulitzer's colorful minidresses were also unique because they were totally antithetical to everything else that was fashionable at the time. In the late 1950s, in fact, women wore corsets and shaping lingerie in order to fit into the clothes they wore. The garments created by Pulitzer, in contrast, slipped on easily and were extremely comfortable. Wendy Vanderbilt with Palm Beach socialites in 1964. A key role in the success of Lilly Pulitzer's line was her circle of famous and influential friends, from Wendy Vanderbilt toJackie Kennedy, who wore one of her polka-dot dresses during a vacation in Capri where she was immortalized by paparazzi alongsideJohn F. Kennedy, her husband and newly elected president of the United States. Over time, her line became so famous that it expanded to include men's and children's garments. Claire, Garrick Stephenson and Donald Leas in 1968 wearing Lilly Pulitzer garments. Over the years, the brand suffered mixed fortunes. Relaunched in the 1990s through Sugartown Worldwide, with creative advice from the designer herself (who passed away in 2013), it adapted to a more contemporary taste, while retaining its playful, colorful soul. Over time, the line became a benchmark for resortwear, the vacation wardrobe made precisely of floaty dresses and caftans with flamboyant prints, comfortable and easy to wear over the bikini, recently brought to the fore by another successful series,The White Lotus, set in the most exclusive vacation destinations on the planet. Lilly Pulitzer's Instagram following of nearly a million followers then indicates that there are many who, a few decades later, continue to be fans of that carefree, slightly nostalgic style that immediately transports one, as if by magic,inside a shot by Slim Aarons, the official photographer of Palm Beach's glossy golden age. At left, Wendy Vanderbilt wearing the signature Lilly Pulitzer shift dress in 1964.
